data.title: What Makes a Good Documentary Film?
data.meta_description: Learn what it takes to make an effective documentary film that captures the viewer's attention and keeps them engaged, including thorough research and storytelling. Discover how you can create a powerful documentary film that will educate and inform audiences!
data.text:
Documentaries can be beautiful and moving, but if it doesn't appeal to a wide audience, it may not be considered "good." When executed correctly, a documentary film can rival the popularity of even fiction films.

Likewise, a documentary can be technically excellent, but if it doesn't have an interesting or compelling story, it may not be considered "good." In the end, it is up to each individual to decide what makes a good documentary.

Types of Documentary Films

There are many different documentary types. Some focus on a specific topic, such as history, nature, or social justice. Others tell the story of a particular person or event. Some are light and entertaining, raising questions such as ‘Do documentaries have to be factual? While others are more serious and thought-provoking. Regardless of their topic or style, all documentary film types should be well-made and provide viewers with a new understanding of the world around them. It is traditionally accepted that 6 types of documentary styles form the sub-genres of the documentary genre itself. These include:

Participatory documentaries

The participatory documentary is a relatively new genre of documentary film. They differ from traditional documentaries in that they allow the audience to participate in the filmmaking process. This can take many different forms, such as providing feedback or suggestions online, sending in photos or videos, or taking part in live forums or chats.

Participatory documentaries often have a more informal feel than traditional documentaries, and the filmmakers often communicate directly with the audience members. This type of documentary is still relatively new, and there is no set formula for how it should be made. However, it is becoming more and more popular, as viewers crave a more interactive experience when watching a documentary.

Performative Documentaries

Performative documentaries put the filmmaker's personal involvement with the subject at the forefront, using their experience or relationship with the subject as a way to explore larger truths about politics, history, or groups of people.

Observational documentary films

Observational documentaries are a type of documentary film that captures the reality of a situation or event. It is often shot without any narration or interviews, letting the footage speak for itself. This type of documentary is often seen as more objective than other types, as it doesn't try to manipulate the viewer's opinion.

Reflexive documentaries

Reflexive documentaries are films that are aware of its own constructedness and often uses metafictional devices to call attention to the fact that it is not a "true" representation of reality.

While reflexive documentaries sound confusing on paper, a good example would be The Thin Blue Line.

Expository documentaries

Expository documentaries are documentaries that are designed to educate viewers about a specific topic or issue. It usually features a presenter who provides information and commentary about the subject matter. One of the best examples of expository documentaries is David Attenborough’s The Blue Planet (2001) or the Natalia documentary, the controversial The Curious Case of Natalia Grace (2023).

Poetic documentaries

Poetic documentaries are a type of documentary that uses poetic devices to create a more artistic and evocative presentation of the subject matter. It often features beautiful visuals and lyrical narration to create a more sensory experience for viewers.

"The Corporation" is a good example of a poetic documentary. It uses stunning visuals and poetic narration to create a powerful and thought-provoking experience for viewers.

What was the First Documentary film?

The Thin Blue Line" (1988)

This documentary film tells the story of a man who was wrongly convicted of murder and sentenced to death row. The film raises questions about the reliability of eyewitness testimony and highlights the flaws in our justice system.

"Grizzly Man" (2005)

Grizzly Man chronicles the life of Timothy Treadwell, a self-proclaimed grizzly bear expert who lived with the bears for 13 summers. Treadwell's story is both tragic and fascinating, raising questions about our relationship with nature and wild animals.

Popular Documentaries about life in America

America: The Story of Us is a 2010 documentary series that chronicles the history of the United States from the early days of settlement to the present day. The series features interviews with a wide range of experts, as well as footage of some of the most important events in American history.

Another noteworthy documentary about life in America is The Civil War, which was produced by Ken Burns in 1990. The nine-part series covers the period from 1861 to 1865, and offers a detailed and intimate look at one of the most tumultuous times in American history.

For those interested in more recent history, Fahrenheit 9/11 is a must-see. The 2004 film examines the events leading up to the September 11th attacks, and offers a critical look at the presidency of George W. Bush.

These three documentaries offer a unique and informative look at different aspects of life in America and are sure to provide viewers with a new understanding of this complex and diverse nation.

Best Thought-Provoking Documentary Films

One of the best ways to learn about other cultures and viewpoints is to watch thought-provoking documentaries. These films offer an in-depth look at a wide range of topics, from environmental issues to social injustice, offering truthful insights a feature film can’t deliver

They can be eye-opening and even life-changing, challenge our preconceptions, and open our minds to new ideas and perspectives. Some of the best thought-provoking documentaries include "The Cove," which raises awareness about the cruel treatment of dolphins in Japan; "Food, Inc.," which examines the dark side of the food industry; and "An Inconvenient Truth," which highlights the dangers of climate change. Watching these documentaries can help us to understand the world around us better and make more informed choices about the way we live our lives.

Popular Documentary Subjects

There are a number of popular documentary subjects that tend to come up again and again in films. Some of the most common subjects include history, politics, nature, and science.

History is a popular subject for documentaries because it allows film directors to explore different aspects of human culture and society. Many history documentaries focus on specific events or time periods, while others take a more broad approach and explore the history of the world as a whole.

Politics is another popular subject for documentaries. This is likely due to the fact that documentaries can be a powerful tool for exploring political issues and exposing corruption. There have been many influential political documentaries over the years, including "The War Room" and "Exit Through the Gift Shop."

Nature documentaries are also very popular and a dream project for filmmakers. They enable directors to capture beautiful and awe-inspiring footage of the natural world, and they often raise awareness about important environmental issues. Some of the most popular nature documentaries include "Earth" and "Planet Earth."

Science documentaries are also very popular. They allow filmmakers to explore different scientific concepts and theories, and they often provide a new perspective on familiar topics. Some of the most popular science documentaries include "Cosmos" and "The Truth About Cancer."

The Future of Documentary Filmmaking

The field of documentary filmmaking has come a long way since the early days of Nanook of the North. In recent years, there have been some major advances in the genre, thanks to new technologies and techniques that have allowed filmmakers to tell more powerful and engaging stories.

One of the biggest advances in documentary filmmaking has been the rise of digital video. With digital video, filmmakers can now capture footage in high definition quality, which allows for a more immersive and realistic viewing experience. Additionally, digital video makes it easier to edit footage, which gives filmmakers more flexibility in terms of how they tell their story. They also inspire as documentary ideas for students.

Another big advance in documentary filmmaking has been the rise of online streaming services like Netflix and Hulu. These services have given documentary filmmakers a new platform to share their work with the world, and they have helped to increase awareness of documentaries as a genre. The Cannes Film Festival in France hosts one of the most prestigious documentary film competitions, called Cannes Docs.
